note:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
altered mental status
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with a PMH of afib, not on
anticoagulation, diastolic heart failure, moderate-severe AS,
hypertension, who presents with altered mental status. 

Patient is currently unable to provide a history due to altered
mental status. History is obtained from her son, ___, over the
phone. He states that he last saw her on ___ (around 5 days
prior to admission) and she was at her baseline. She is normally
coherent, able to have full sentences. Between ___ night 
and
___ morning she had a significant change. On ___ when she
was seen by a new health aid it was noted that she was not
talking, not cooperating with her aid, and not getting out of
bed. There were no known falls or headstrikes, and she had not
been complaining of anything in particular prior to this. When
taken to the hospital she was unable to recognize her family
members, though she did intermittently say a few words. 

She was first brought to ___ where she was found to
have a temp of 98, HR 74, BP 141/87, RR 18, satting 98% on room
air. Labs were notable for a normal CBC, and lytes (Cr 1.2), u/a
with positive nitrates, moderate leuk esterase, 5 WBCs, many
bacteria. She was started on ceftriaxone and given a full dose
aspirin (unclear reason). She was transferred to the ED at ___
for "UTI with metabolic encephalopathy". (Of note, her family 
had
requested that she be transferred to ___, where she had
been seen previously.)

Her son notes that her right arm is often in an odd position,
almost as though she was paralyzed on that side, which he had
noticed over the years. It often seems to be tender, and he has
noted that she does not use it often.

Her son also notes that she has been taking her evening pills in
the morning because she had been falling asleep prior to using
them. This includes her pills for insomnia. He states that he 
has
never heard of atrial fibrillation before and is not aware of 
any
diagnosis. 

He notes that she previously was on a lot of medications, and
that the number has really be cut down over the past few years.
She stopped taking several because she was feeling dizzy. He
believes that she may have been on a blood thinner and something
for pain. He notes that she doesn't know how to use the 
albuterol
inhaler and has no idea what it is for - she does not use this.
He is otherwise not sure what she is taking at home. 

On review of records, patient has been hospitalized twice at
___ in the past ___ years. In ___ she was admitted for
hypoxic respiratory failure from a heart failure exacerbation.
She was diuresed and discharged on Lasix. She was also treated
for afib with RVR, which was a new diagnosis at the time. She 
was
started on apixaban. She was found to have moderate to severe AS
on TTE. Course was also complicated by GPC bacteremia, thought 
to
be from cellulitis. 

She was readmitted in ___ again with a heart failure
exacerbation, requiring ICU admission for BiPAP. During this
admission she again was found to have afib with RVR, which
improved. However, it was noted that her apixaban had been
stopped in between the hospitalizations secondary to several
falls that she was having. Course was also complicated by
hospital acquired delirium. 

In the ED:

Initial vital signs were notable for: T 98, HR 83, BP 143/83, RR
18, 97% RA 

Exam notable for:
Neuro: Alert and following commands, moving all extremities
spontaneously, not cooperating with neurological exam due to
altered mental status., ANO x1
Psych: Normal mood/altered mental status

Labs were notable for:

- CBC: WBC 6.0, hgb 12.3, plt 189 

- Lytes:

140 / 99 / 18     AGap=13 
------------- 109 
4.4 \ 28 \ 1.2 

- LFTs: AST: 21 ALT: 9 AP: 80 Tbili: 0.6 Alb: 4.3 
- lipase 18
- lactate 1.7
- u/a with small leuks, small blood, positive nitrites, 6 WBCs,
few bacteria 

Studies performed include:
- CT a/p w/ contrast  -  Mildly thickened urinary bladder wall
with subtle fat stranding, consistent with provided history of
urinary tract infection. No evidence of renal calculi.

Second reds were done on OSH CT head w/o contrast, CT c-spine 
w/o
contrast, and CT chest w/o contrast:
- CT head - no acute intracranial abnormality
- CT spine - no acute cervical spine fracture
- CT chest - no acute intrathoracic abnormality, scattered
pulmonary nodules, dilated ascending and descending thoracic
aorta as well as dilation of the great vessels 

Patient was given:

___ 08:31 PO/NG Aspirin 81 mg

___ 08:31 PO/NG Labetalol 200 mg 
___ 15:48 PO/NG Labetalol 200 mg

___ 20:31 PO/NG Atorvastatin 10 mg  
___ 20:31 PO/NG Labetalol 200 mg 

Vitals on transfer: T 98.3, HR 76, BP 133/74, RR 18, 96% RA 

Upon arrival to the floor, patient is alert and tracks
intermittently, but does not answer questions or follow most
commands. She occasionally will say ___ words such as "ouch". 
 
Past Medical History:
- atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation
- moderate-severe aortic stenosis
- diastolic heart failure 
- insomnia
- hypertension
- hyperlipidemia 
- frequent falls 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Reviewed and found to be not relevant to this illness/reason for 
hospitalization.
 
Physical Exam:
Admission Physical Exam:
========================
VITALS: T 98.5, HR 75, BP 133/71, RR 18, 94% RA 
GENERAL: Alert, tracks at times with eyes and at times will nod
or shake head to questions, though unclear if meaningful. Not
answering verbally though occasionally will say "ouch". No acute
distress  
EYES: Anicteric, pupils ~1-2mm, difficult to assess if reactive
to light
ENT: Ears and nose without visible erythema, masses, or trauma. 
Oropharynx without visible lesion, erythema or exudate though
patient will not open mouth fully for good examination
CV: Heart irregularly irregular with ___ systolic ejection 
murmur
best heard at RUSB, no S3, no S4.  No JVD.
RESP: Lungs clear to auscultation with good air movement
bilaterally.  Breathing is non-labored
GI: Abdomen soft, non-distended, patient grimaces to palpation
diffusely.  Bowel sounds present.  No HSM
GU: No suprapubic fullness or tenderness to palpation
MSK: Neck supple, right hand contracted and patient states 
"ouch"
when we try to open her hand. Does not move right arm
spontaneously. Feet somewhat contracted, and moves left leg side
to side. 
SKIN: No rashes or ulcerations noted
NEURO: Alert, nonverbal, appears to have R-sided facial droop
(unknown chronicity). Pupils pinpoint, tracks at times. Closes
both eyes symmetrically. Does not smile to command. Right arm
contracted and does not move spontaneously. Moves left arm
spontaneously and grips to command. When asked to wiggle toes,
shakes her head "no". Seen moving left leg side to side, not 
seen
moving right leg. 
PSYCH: unable to assess 

Discharge Physical Exam:
========================
VITALS: 98.3 PO 111 / 75 L Lying 78 20 97 Ra 
GENERAL: Alert, tracks at times with eyes and at times will nod 
or shake head to questions. Not answering verbally
EYES: Anicteric, pupils ~1-2mm, round and reactive to light, R 
pupil smaller than left
ENT: Ears and nose without visible erythema, masses, or trauma. 
Oropharynx without visible lesion, erythema or exudate though
patient will not open mouth fully for good examination.
CV: Heart irregularly irregular. No JVD.
RESP: Breathing is non-labored
GI: Abdomen soft, non-distended, non-tender
GU: No foley
MSK: Neck supple. Active resistance to passive movement of upper
extremities RUE. Moving lower extremities
SKIN: No rashes or ulcerations noted
NEURO: Alert, nonverbal. tracks at times. Closes both eyes 
symmetrically. Does not smile to command. L thumbs up to 
command. R NLFF and asymmetry with smile, hearing appears intact 
to voice, tongue is midline. Right arm contracted, does exert 
resistance with passive movement, cries in pain with any 
attempted movement, including the fingers. Moves left arm 
spontaneously.

1. No acute cervical spine fracture.
2. Multilevel degenerative changes of the cervical spine.
3. Dilated thoracic aorta and great arteries.
4. 4 mm right upper lobe pulmonary nodule, recommend follow-up 
per the
___ criteria as detailed below.

1. Mildly thickened urinary bladder wall with subtle fat 
stranding, consistent with provided history of urinary tract 
infection.  No evidence of renal calculi.

be
hemodynamically significant.

CTA Head/Neck:
1. No acute intracranial abnormality.
2. Patent circle of ___ without evidence of 
stenosis,occlusion,or aneurysm.
3. Main then the limitation of poor contrast visualization, 
patent bilateral cervical carotid and vertebral arteries without 
evidence of stenosis, occlusion, or dissection.

MRI Head:
1. T2 FLAIR hyperintensities demonstrating decreased diffusion

2. Multiple other small punctate acute infarcts are seen in the 
left frontal lobe, basal ganglia and the) right periventricular 
region regions.  No signs of hemorrhage.
3. Additional T2 FLAIR hyperintensities in the periventricular 
white matter
that are suggestive of moderate chronic small vessel ischemic 
disease.
4. No enhancing brain lesions.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with a PMH of afib, not on 
anticoagulation, diastolic heart failure, moderate-severe AS, 
hypertension, who presented with altered mental status, found to 
have acute CVAs with resultant expressive aphasia, 
encephalopathy, possible UTI.

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS:
# Toxic metabolic encephalopathy:
# Acute CVAs:
Patient became acutely altered in a short time, and her exam on 
admission had some focal findings including a right-sided facial 
droop and right arm and leg weakness (though will note that 
right arm findings may be chronic per son and exam was difficult 
due to patient's inability to follow commands reliably). Her 
head CT showed no acute findings, though a chronic infarct was 
seen in the left frontal lobe. CTA head/neck revealed chronic 
atherosclerosis and no acute infarct. MRI was obtained which 
then demonstrated with multiple punctate infarcts in the left 
frontal lobe, basal ganglia and the right periventricular region 
regions. She was also found to have decreased diffusion the left 
vertex along the distribution of left anterior cerebral artery 
middle cerebral artery watershed region are suggestive of acute 
infarct. Stroke was felt to likely be secondary to embolic 
origin from atrial fibrillation, with a possible component of 
watershed infarct in the left ACA distribution due to chronic 
severe carotid disease. Home atorvastatin was increased from 
10mg to 40mg. Home labetalol was stopped to allow for permissive 
hypertension. TTE was somewhat limited though there was no 
obvious vegetation or clot visualized. She was seen by neurology 
who recommended anticoagulation with a heparin drip. She 
remained stable on heparin and repeat head CT was obtained which 
showed no evidence of hemorrhage. She was then transitioned to 
apixaban 5mg BID. Home aspirin was stopped per neurology 
recommendations due to increased bleeding of risk on 
anticoagulation.

# UTI: Found to have bladder wall thickening on CT and urine 
culture grew ESBL E coli. Given altered mental status and 
inability to assess for symptoms (in addition to possibility of 
UTI contributing to altered mental status and recrudescence of 
prior L sided stroke symptoms), she was treated with bactrim for 
a 10 day course (day 7 = ___, however UA only had 6 WBC and 
few bacteria so it is possible this was colonization.

# Afib: Not a new diagnosis, and rates currently 
well-controlled. Not on anticoagulation at home due to previous 
falls. Labetalol initially was held in the setting of acute 
stroke, then resumed. Rates were well controlled with half of 
home dose, therefore discharged on 100 mg TID. Started apixaban 
for anticoagulation as above.

# ___
Mild, BUN overall doubled during this hospitalization, was 
initially receiving diuretic, then held Lasix and gave small 
amount of fluids back. Likely due to decreased PO intake on 
modified diet. 

# Dilated ascending and descending thoracic aorta: incidentally 
seen on imaging, unclear if new finding. Can monitor as an 
outpatient. Continued blood pressure control with labetalol.

# Code status: MOLST signed by patient on ___ confirms 
DNR/DNI. Discussed with HCP ___. He was not previously aware of 
his mother's wishes to be DNR/DNI. Discussed that given her 
advanced age and multiple medical comorbidities, the chances of 
her surviving a code with any meaningful quality of life would 
be very low. Code status was changed to DNR/DNI and updated 
MOLST was filled out while hospitalized, though no changes were 
made to preferences on prior MOLST form.

# Pulmonary nodules 
Found to have incidental 4mm pulmonary nodule. For incidentally 
detected multiple solid pulmonary nodules smaller than 6mm, no 
CT follow-up is recommended in a low-risk patient, and an 
optional CT follow-up in 12 months is recommended in a high-risk 
patient. 

CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS:
# Chronic diastolic heart failure 
# Moderate-severe aortic stenosis 
Continued home Lasix initially, however patient was not eating 
and drinking that well and started to develop a mild ___, 
therefore this was held. Please resume when possible.

# HLD:
Stopped home aspirin per neurology recommendations due to 
increased risk of bleeding on anticoagulation. Increased home 
atorvastatin from 10mg to 40mg

# Hypertension 
Initially held home labetalol to allow for permissive 
hypertension, then resumed at reduced dose 

# Insomnia 
Held home trazodone due to altered mental status, started 
ramelteon, which patient took intermittently. Resumed trazodone 
on discharge.

>30 minutes spent discharge planning and coordination on day of 
discharge.

Transitional Issues:
====================
- home aspirin stopped due to increased risk of bleeding on 
anticoagulation
- started on apixaban 5mg BID for anticoagulation
- home atorvastatin increased from 10mg to 40mg
- could consider 12 month follow up CT for incidental pulmonary 
nodule if high risk, though likely not necessary given advanced 
age and functional status
- on nectar thick liquids and pureed solids, will need continued 
speech and swallow evaluation with diet advancement if possible 
(family may also elect to advance to regular diet for comfort)
- labetalol reduced, please monitor heart rates and BP and 
titrate as needed
- dilated ascending and descending thoracic aorta incidentally 
seen on imaging, can monitor as an outpatient
- Code status changed to DNR/DNI, MOLST completed
- home Lasix on hold, please resume when PO intake improves  
- repeat TTE routinely; inpatient TTE was limited in assessment 
of severity of aortic stenosis
- ESBL E coli found in the urine, if needs empiric outpatient 
treatment for UTI would use Bactrim rather than cipro, macrobid 
as she had resistance to these

Extended Care

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - sometimes.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You came into the hospital because you were confused and were 
having difficulty speaking. We found that you had unfortunately 
had several new strokes, likely caused by your atrial 
fibrillation (abnormal heart rhythm).
You were seen by the neurologists, who recommended starting a 
blood thinner to prevent any future strokes.

While you were here you were also treated for a urinary tract 
infection with antibiotics.

You are now going to rehab to work on getting stronger and 
speaking more.

It was a pleasure taking care of you, and we are happy that 
you're feeling better!
Your ___ Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
